Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Louis Stokes Alliances for Minority Participation (LSAMP) program assists universities and colleges in their efforts to significantly increase the numbers of students matriculating into and successfully completing high quality degree programs in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) disciplines in order to diversify the STEM workforce. Particular emphasis is placed on transforming undergraduate STEM education through innovative, evidence-based recruitment and retention strategies, and relevant educational experiences in support of racial and ethnic groups historically underrepresented in STEM disciplines: African Americans, Hispanic Americans, American Indians, Alaska Natives, Native Hawaiians, and Native Pacific Islanders. These strategies facilitate the production of well-prepared students highly-qualified and motivated to pursue graduate education or careers in STEM.

For the United States (U.S.) to remain globally competitive, it is vital that it taps into the talent of all its citizens and provides exceptional educational preparedness in STEM areas that underpin the knowledge-based economy. In the spirit of this endeavor, Brookhaven National Laboratory (BNL), a US Department of Energy (DOE) multi-discipline research laboratory proposes to pilot a 3-week "Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (LSAMP) SciComp Skills Building Internship Program" with the goal of enabling LSAMP students to develop scientific computing skills to integrate into their regular STEM academic activities and scientific research, thereby increasing their competitiveness and preparation for internship programs and graduate research.

This activity has significant societal potential for: (1) increasing the number and quality of underrepresented minority (URM) students at LSAMP institutions who are accepted for participation in advanced science internship programs across the Department of Energy (DOE) complex, (2) advancing knowledge in the STEM disciplines through the promotion of interdisciplinary research activity, and (3) contributing to a more globally competitive STEM workforce who can adeptly wield the power of computing to advance scientific discovery. The intent is to inspire students to pursue a career in the exciting field of scientific computing and/or apply scientific computing to other fields of scientific discovery. Furthermore, the integration of LSAMP program participants and their administrators will strengthen the relationship between the NSF LSAMP program and the DOE research enterprise to increase URM employment at national laboratories and as users of their world-class facilities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Brookhaven National Laboratory (BNL) Office of Educational Programs (OEP) was awarded funding from the National Science Foundation (NSF) Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (LSAMP) to conduct a three-week internship program to encourage twenty (20) NSF LSAMP Scholars to develop scientific computing skills to integrate into their regular STEM academic activities and scientific research thereby increasing their competitiveness and preparation for internship programs and graduate research. Through a series of thirty (30) hands-on programming exercises, LSAMP Scholars learned and applied the same data structures and algorithms used by BNL scientists to tackle modern research challenges. 

The goals of this internship program are to: (1) increase the number of underrepresented minority students who enter STEM related research programs at DOE national laboratories, other federal agencies, and other world-class research facilities; (2) train students on how to utilize modern software tools to enhance their current STEM related work in their existing undergraduate research efforts; and (3) increase the participation of women in the field of scientific computing. 

A total of twenty (20) LSAMP Scholars were recruited to participate in this SciComp Internship program from the nationwide LSAMP network. These scholars came from eight Alliances - the Alabama AMP (2); North Carolina AMP (1); Oklahoma AMP (1); Peach State AMP(5); Greater Philadelphia AMP (4); Puerto Rico AMP (2); State University of New York AMP (4) and the University of Texas System AMP (1). There were 13 (65%) females and eight (35%) males with majors in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) disciplines such as Chemistry (5), Biology (7), Mechanical Engineering (2), Electrical Engineering (1), Information Technology (2), Physics (1) and Interdisciplinary Studies (1). The program assisted these scholars in understanding and appreciating the value of computer coding (Python and C++) and the utilization of the Amazon Cloud in solving complex topics in scientific research.  Thirteen scholars (65%) have self-reported of advancing on to graduate school and participating in internship programs while others have indicated using this newly understood skills in their classrooms and labs back at their home institutions. Nine (69%) of these thirteen self-reporting scholars were females who are engaged in one form or other in scientific computing.  All participants have remained in STEM. 

As part of this grant, OEP submitted a supplemental request and was awarded funding to support a initial 6-month internship with an additional two-month extension at Brookhaven National Laboratory (BNL) for Mr. William Serrano-Garcia from October 01, 2018 to May 31, 2019 to study the fabrication and characterization of organic semiconductor devices. Mr. Serrano-Garcia, a doctoral student in the Electrical Engineering Department at the University of South Florida (USF), was supported for two years by the NSF Florida-Georgia LSAMP Bridge to the Doctorate Project. A primary goal of his dissertation research with Dr. Sylvia Thomas at USF is to mature the device technology for nanofiber p-n junction coaxial structures formed with semiconducting polymers via electrospinning for electronic devices. The research objective of this internship and collaboration with Dr. Chang-Yong Nam from BNL’s Center for Functional Nanomaterials (CFN) was to investigate organic semiconductive polymers utilized to form 1 dimension (1D) coaxial p-n junctions for organic/hybrid photovoltaics and sensors and their characterization expecting better performance and lower power requirements. 

For the first time the collaboration collected data and reported the sensing response and interaction mechanisms of the ladder polymer Poly(benzimidazobenzophenanthroline) (BBL) for different volatile organic compounds (VOC’s). The findings opened a new level of possibilities for ladder like polymers in electronic device applications. While this polymer has been previously used for field effect transistors (FET’s) and solar cells (SC’s) applications, sensors and its mechanism has not been studied, making this work essential extending the applications of this robust and electroactive ladder polymer. This work will result in the formulation and analysis of data for the submission of a future publication. 

Due to this internship at BNL, Mr. Serrano-Garcia obtained another internship at Idaho National Laboratory during the 2019 Summer and has since won a Fulbright fellowship to Singapore where he is presently completing a one-year research tenure in September 2020.  These two experiences will result in two publications for Mr. Serrano-Garcia and his collaborators. 

Broader Impacts for the SciComp Internship Program include: (1) increasing the number and quality of underrepresented minority students at AMP institutions who are accepted for participation in advanced science internship programs across the Department of Energy (DOE) complex, (2) advancing knowledge in the STEM disciplines through the promotion of interdisciplinary research activity, and (3) contributing to a more globally competitive STEM workforce who can adeptly wield the power of computing to advance scientific discovery.  The intent is to inspire students to possibly pursue a career in the exciting field of scientific computing.
